lesson.name: Lesson 8.2: When and Why Do We Write Quadratic Equations?

page.title: 8.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will analyze and interpret given equations, write equations to represent relationships and constraints, and work to solve these equations. Ultimately, you will see that sometimes solutions to quadratic equations cannot be easily or precisely found by graphing or reasoning.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Recognize the factored form of a quadratic expression and know when it can be useful for solving problems.
  • Use a graph to find the solutions to a quadratic equation but also know its limitations.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.2.1: Interpreting Equations in Context
  • 8.2.2: Exploring Non-Graphing Strategies to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • 8.2.2: Self Check
    • 8.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.2.3: Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero
    • 8.2.3: Self Check
    • 8.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.2.4: Solving a Real-World Problem Using Quadratic Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 8.2.5: Practice
  • 8.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.2.1: Interpreting Equations in Context
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Tickets to a play cost $12, and for each purchase there is a $2.50 fee. The expression \(12t + 2.50\) represents the cost to purchase tickets for the play, where \(t\) is the number of tickets. Be prepared to explain your response to each question.


  1. A family paid $62.50 for tickets. How many tickets were bought?

Enter the number of tickets.

Compare your answer:

Five tickets were bought. Subtracting 2.50 from 62.50 gives 60. If \(12t\) is 60, then \(t\) is 5.

  1. A teacher paid $278.50 for tickets for her students. How many tickets were bought?

Enter the number of tickets.

Compare your answer:

Twenty-three tickets were bought. Subtracting 2.50 from 278.50 gives 276. If \(12t\) is 276, then \(t\) is 23.

page.title: 8.2.2: Exploring Non-Graphing Strategies to Solve Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Activity

In a previous lesson, you saw an equation that defines the height of a potato as a function of time after it was launched from a mechanical device. Here is a different function modeling the height of a potato, in feet, \(t\) seconds after being fired from a different device:

\(f(t) = -16t^2 + 80t + 64\)


  1. What equation would we solve to find the time at which the potato hits the ground?

Enter an equation.

Compare your answer:

\(-16t^2 + 80t + 64 = 0\)

Since the potato hits the ground at a height of 0 feet, set the equation equal to 0.


  1. Use any method except graphing to find a solution to the equation from the previous question.

Enter a solution to the equation.

Compare your answer:

An approximate solution is about 5.7 seconds by using trial and error.

page.title: 8.2.2: Self Check
page.contents:
After a flashlight is turned on, it gets brighter as it warms up, and then it grows dimmer as the battery dies. The equation modeling the brightness it emits, in lumens, \(h\) hours after being turned on is shown here.

\(f(h) = -8h^2 + 30h + 50\)

Which equation would you solve to determine when the flashlight dies and stops emitting lumens?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation does not represent when the flashlight dies. The sign on 50 should not have been reversed. The answer is \(-8h^2 + 30h + 50 = 0\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation does not represent when the flashlight dies. The sign on \(8h^2\) should not have been reversed. The answer is \(-8h^2 + 30h + 50 = 0\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation does not represent when the flashlight dies. The answer is \(-8h^2 + 30h + 50 = 0\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: By setting the equation equal to 0, we are representing the time when the flashlight is no longer emitting any light (0 lumens).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Various Methods to Solve Quadratic Equations

A tennis ball is thrown out of the window of a building. The equation modeling the height of the tennis ball, in feet, \(t\) seconds after being thrown is shown here.

\(f(t) = -24t^2 + 33t + 30\)

Let’s find the equation we would solve to find the time at which the ball hits the ground. 

When the ball hits the ground, its height will be 0. So, we set the equation to 0.

\(-24t^2 + 33t + 30 = 0\)

The equation above represents the ball when it hits the ground. The solution to this equation represents the time it takes from when the ball is thrown for it to hit the ground.

Let’s try to solve the equation.

Step 1
Write the equation to be solved.
\(-24t^2 + 33t + 30 = 0\)

Step 2
Subtract 30 from each side of the equation.
\(-24t^2 + 33t = -30\)

Step 3
Divide each side of the equation by 3.
\(-8t^2 + 11t = -10\)

Let’s try to solve the remaining equation using guess and check.

When \(t = 3\), the expression \(-8t^2 + 11t\) has a value of \(-8(3)^2 + 11(3)\), or \(-39\). This value is not equal to the \(-10\) we needed to find. 

When \(t = 2\), the expression \(-8t^2 + 11t\) has a value of \(-8(2)^2 + 11(2)\), or \(-10\). This value is equal to the \(-10\) we needed to find. 

The equation is true when \(t = 2\), so the ball took 2 seconds to hit the ground. This method works but can be more difficult when the solution is a decimal. Graphing can also work, but it is time consuming and results in an approximate solution.

Try It: Using Various Methods to Solve Quadratic Equations

An arc of water flows from a water fountain down to a pool below it. The height of the arc above the pool, in inches, can be modeled using the equation \(f(x) = -2x^2 + 5x + 3\), where \(x\) is the horizontal distance the water has traveled, in inches, from the water fountain.

  1. Which equation would you solve to determine how far the arc of water has traveled horizontally when it reaches the pool below?
  1. Solve the equation using a non-graphing method.

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write and solve the equation representing the arc of water from the water fountain:

  1. The equation \(-2x^2 + 5x + 3 = 0\) represents the arc of the water when it reaches the pool below.
  1. To solve the equation \(-2x^2 + 5x + 3 = 0\), let’s try using guess and check with substitution. 

First, we try \(x = 2\).

\(-2(2)^2+5(2)+3\overset?=0\)
\(5 \neq 0\)

Now, let’s try \(x = 3\).

\(-2(3)^2+5(3)+3\overset?=0\)
\(0 = 0\)

Since the equation is true, \(x = 3\) is correct.

The arc of water has traveled 3 inches horizontally when it reaches the pool below the fountain.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.2.3: Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero
page.contents:
Activity

The expressions \(p(200 − 5p)\) and \(-5p^2 + 200p\) define the same function. The function models the revenue a school would earn from selling raffle tickets at \(p\) dollars each.


  1. At what price or prices would the school collect $0 revenue from raffle sales? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

$0 and $40. For example, if the equation \(p(200−5p)=0\) is true, then either \(p\) is equal to 0, or \(200−5p\) is equal to 0. If \(200−5p=0\), then \(p\) is 40, because \(200−5(40)\) is 0.


  1. The school staff noticed that there are two ticket prices that would result in a revenue of $500. What equation could you use to determine what those two prices are?

Enter an equation.

Compare your answer:

We could write \(p(200 − 5p) = 500\) and \(-5p^2 + 200p = 500\). Approximate solutions can be found using trial and error or graphing. However, we don’t yet know an exact way to solve either equation.



Extending Your Thinking

Can you find the following prices without graphing?

  1. If the school charges $10, it will collect $1500 in revenue. Find another price that would generate $1500 in revenue.

Enter another price.

Compare your answer:

$30

Moving the same distance away from each horizontal intercept, at $0 and $40, results in equal revenue. This means $10 and $30 earn an equal amount of revenue.


  1. If the school charges $28, it will collect $1680 in revenue. Find another price that would generate $1680 in revenue.

Enter another price.

Compare your answer:

$12

Moving the same distance away from each horizontal intercept, at $0 and $40, results in equal revenue. This means $12 and $28 earn an equal amount of revenue.


  1. Find the price that would produce the maximum possible revenue. Explain your reasoning.

Enter the price that would produce the maximum possible revenue.

Compare your answer:

$20. Moving the same distance away from each horizontal intercept results in equal revenue. The farther away we move from one horizontal intercept in the direction of the other intercept, the greater the revenue. An optimal ticket price of $20, producing $2000 in revenue, is found in the middle point between the two intercepts, at \(p = 20\).


Video: Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero

Watch the following video to learn more about solving a quadratic equation set equal to zero.

page.title: 8.2.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The expressions \(s(60 − 12s)\) and \(-122 + 60s\) define the same function. A soap bubble machine can launch many soap bubbles into the air before they begin to pop. The function given models the number of soap bubbles floating in the air in \(s\) seconds.

According to the function, how many seconds have passed before all of the bubbles have been made and also popped?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At 0 seconds, there are no bubbles. However, the bubbles have not been made and popped yet. The answer is 5 seconds.

That’s correct! Check yourself: The time passed when all of the bubbles are popped is represented by the equation \(s(60 − 12s) = 0\). Substitute 5 in for \(s\) to check your answer. Since \((5)(60 - 12(5)) = 0\), the answer is correct.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Solve the equation \(s(60 − 12s) = 0\) to find the solution. Do this by setting the factor \(60 − 12s\) equal to 0 and solving to find the nonzero solution. The answer is 5 seconds.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Solve the equation \(s(60 − 12s) = 0\) to find the solution. Do this by setting the factor \(60 − 12s\) equal to 0 and solving to find the nonzero solution. The answer is 5 seconds.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero

The expressions \(h(40 − 10h)\) and \(-10h^2 + 40h\) define the same function. The function models the height of a weather balloon in miles \(h\) hours after it is released.

  1. What equation can be used to determine the times the weather balloon is on the ground?

Solution:
When the weather balloon is on the ground, the expression will equal 0. So, the equation \(h(40 − 10h) = 0\) represents the weather balloon when it is on the ground.

  1. How can we solve the equation \(h(40 − 10h) = 0\)?

Solution:
We know that any value multiplied by 0 equals 0. So, if \(h\) or \((40 - 10h)\) equals 0, then the left side of the equation will also equal 0.

The weather balloon is on the ground at 0 hours. Now, let’s find the solution to \(40 - 10h = 0\).

\(40 - 10h = 0\)

\(40 = 10h\)

\(4 = h\)

The weather balloon is also on the ground after 4 hours.

  1. A scientist wants to determine the two different times when the weather balloon is 30 miles above Earth. Write an equation to represent these times.

Solution:
The times when the weather balloon is 30 miles above Earth are represented by the equation \(h(40 − 10h) = 30\) or the equation \(-10h^2 + 40h = 30\).

  1. If the weather balloon is 30 miles above Earth after 1 hour, find another time that the weather balloon is 30 miles above Earth.

Solution:
We know the total trip takes the weather balloon 4 hours. Since the graph representing the flight of the weather balloon is symmetric, if it takes 1 hour to reach 30 miles up, then 1 hour from touching the ground, it will be at 30 miles up again. So, the weather balloon will be 30 miles above Earth after 3 hours.

Try It: Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero

The expressions \(p(420 − 60p)\) and \(-60p^2 + 420p\) define the same function. The function models revenue earned at a baseball game from the sale of baseball magazines sold at \(p\) dollars each.

  1. At what price or prices would the game organizers collect $0 revenue from magazine sales? Explain or show your reasoning.
  1. The organizers determined there are two magazine prices that would result in a revenue of $600. What equation would you use to determine what those two prices are?

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to use your knowledge of quadratic equations to solve the problem:

  1. $0 and $7. If the equation \(p(420 − 60p) = 0\) is true, then either \(p\) is equal to 0, or \(420 − 60p\) is equal to 0. If \(420 − 60p = 0\), then \(p\) is 7, because \(420 − 60(7)\) is 0.
  1. We could write \(p(420 − 60p) = 600\) or \(-60p^2 + 420p = 600\). We can use trial and error or graphing to provide approximate solutions. We do not yet know an exact method to solve either equation.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.2.4: Solving a Real-World Problem Using Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A movie theater models the revenue from ticket sales in one day as a function of the ticket price, \(p\). Here are two expressions defining the same revenue function.

\(p(120 − 4p)\)

\(120p − 4p^2\)


  1. According to this model, how high would the ticket price have to be for the theater to make $0 in revenue? Explain your reasoning.

Enter the ticket price and your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

$30. If \(p(120 − 4p) = 0\), then either \(p = 0\) or \(120 − 4p = 0\). If the latter is a true equation, \(p\) must be 30.


  1. What equation can you write to find out what ticket price(s) would allow the theater to make $600 in revenue?

Enter an equation.

Compare your answer:

\(p(120−4p) = 600\) or \(120p − 4p^2 = 600\)

page.title: 8.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The expression \(t + 7.25\) represents the cost to purchase tickets for a concert, where \(t\) is the number of tickets. A group of friends paid $79.25 for tickets. How many tickets were bought?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.2.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 8 tickets. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 2–4.

A model rocket is launched from a launchpad. The function modeling the height of the rocket, in feet, \(t\) seconds after being launched is shown.

\(f(t) = -15t^2 + 58t + 8\)

  1. Which equation would you solve to find the time at which the rocket hits the ground?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 8.2.2 and 8.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(-15t^2 + 58t + 8 = 0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use a non-graphing method to find the solution to the previous equation to determine the time that has passed when the rocket hits the ground.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.2.2 and 8.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How high off the ground is the launchpad from which the rocket lifts off?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 8.2.2 and 8.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 8 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 5–8.

The expressions \(t(90 − 3t)\) and \(-3t^2 + 90t\) define the same function. The function models the number of lumens emitted by a spotlight in an art exhibit over the course of \(t\) seconds.

  1. Which equation represents the time when the spotlight is not emitting any light?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 8.2.2 and 8.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(-3t^2 + 90t = 0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. At what time(s) does the spotlight not emit any light?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 0 and 30 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The artist planned for the spotlight to emit 600 lumens at 10 seconds from the start. At what other time will the spotlight emit 600 lumens of light?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 20 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. At 5 seconds, the spotlight will emit 375 lumens. Find another time that the spotlight emits 375 lumens.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.2.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 25 seconds. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 9 and 10.

A bowling alley models the revenue from sales in one day as a function of the cost to rent a lane per hour, \(c\). Here are two expressions defining the same revenue function.

\(c(160 − 10c)\)

\(160c − 10^2\)

  1. According to this model, how high would the cost to rent a lane have to be for the bowling alley to make $0 in revenue?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is $16. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What equation can you write to determine the lane cost that would allow the bowling alley to make $640 in revenue?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.2.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(c(160 − 10c) = 640\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Recognize the factored form of a quadratic expression and know when it can be useful for solving problems.
  • Use a graph to find the solutions to a quadratic equation but also know its limitations.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.2.1: Interpreting Equations in Context
    • In this activity, you interpreted an equation representing a real-world situation to answer different questions about that situation.
  • 8.2.2: Exploring Non-Graphing Strategies to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you tried to solve a quadratic equation using trial and error. You learned that a strategy such as this might be difficult to use when the solutions are harder to find.
    • 8.2.2: Self Check
    • 8.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.2.3: Solving a Quadratic Equation Set Equal to Zero
    • In this activity, you continued exploring how to solve quadratic equations. You learned that a quadratic equation that has been set equal to zero provides more opportunities for how to solve it. You set quadratic equations equal to zero when possible to find solutions in context.
    • 8.2.3: Self Check
    • 8.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.2.4: Solving a Real-World Problem Using Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you solved a real-world problem using the skills learned in the lesson. By developing a better understanding of quadratic equations, you also better understand the context of a real-world situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.2.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
